Award.AbstractNarration:
The research proposed includes a broad range of topics in computability theory and logic both theoretical and applied to other areas of mathematics and computer science with some possible commercial or industrial applications as well. Broadly speaking, the major research proposed by the PI is directed at analyzing complexity and relative complexity. One area of study concerns functions on the natural numbers and then more broadly general mathematical structures. The primary measuring rod for this investigation is Turing's notion of relative computability which captures our usual intuitions and corresponds to computations by idealized versions of standard computing machines and program languages. The other major thrust of the proposed research is directed at an analysis of the complexity of mathematical theorems and constructions. Here, one compares the complexity of the inputs/hypotheses to that of the outputs/conclusions of the constructions/theorems. Strength is measured both computationally and in terms of the axioms needed to prove the theorem or correctness of the construction. The co-PI has proposed directing research in areas of logic with applications to computer science including the study of very simple machine models as well as logical languages useful for verifying that computer programs do what they are designed to do and not other (perhaps dangerous) things. He is also involved in developing and patenting methods for quantum control of ordinary (macro)processes. While this work has been influenced by his previously supported theoretical work, it now lies outside the scope of this proposal.

At a more technical level, the PI's proposals deal with analyzing the structure of the Turing degrees (of relative complexity of computation) and of particularly important substructures. The emphasis here is on questions of definability and nondefinability as well as (bi)interpretations of arithmetic in the relevant structures. Particular emphasis will be placed on relations to external notions such as rates of growth for functions and the complexity of the definitions in arithmetic or other languages of the functions or structures. His other major focus is on reverse mathematics. In particular, the analysis of theorems that, in terms of their proof theoretic and computational strength, lie outside the scope of the standard systems studied. Thus it demonstrates that there are many truly distinct types of construction principles occupying different levels of complexity with involved relations among them. Problems to be studied come from the realms of combinatorics, algebra, model theory and determinacy. The co-PI's proposals primarily deal with automata theory, particularly as related to control theory, and modal logics used to capture notions of awareness and belief.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research conducted under this award was centered on mathematical logic. There were two main areas addressed. The first concerned measuring the complexity of mathematical principles based on several related measures. One is the computational complexity of the functions or other objects asserted to exist with respect to the complexity of given inputs. The measures here are primarily based on actions by Turing machines (idealized computers). Another measure is in terms of the strength of the axioms needed to prove the existence of the desired functions. Here, again, one has several yardsticks that correspond to common assumptions and theorems. Both these approaches provide results of the form that there is or is not a computable solution to a given problem or, alternatively, characterizes what additional information or computing power would be necessary to solve it. Mathematical subjects investigated in these ways centered on combinatorics, algebra and model theory. These results are of both mathematical and foundational (philosophical) interest and importance.

    A second important theme in the area of computational complexity was the investigation of the abstract ordering on functions given by f is (Turing) below g if there is a Turing machine which when given access to g can compute f. Along these lines were investigations of the relations among several other measures of complexity such as the rates of growth of the functions and level of complexity of their definitions (e.g. in arithmetic).


    The second general area  investigated concerned both automata theory (very simple machines much weaker than Turing machines) with additional operators corresponding to common manipulations. A related topic investigated was modal logics. Thee are logics for languages that extend beyond the common mathematical ones by allowing discussion of topics such as belief, knowledge, time and other notions of interest both in philosophy and computer science with applications to many areas including game theory and economics. One student developed methods for analyzing situations involving risk/reward benefits that explained several procedures often used by people in practice but that did not fit the standard models for analysis of "rational" economic behavior. These results make contributions to mathematics, computer science, philosophy and economics.


    Approximately ten Ph.D. students were supported by this grant. Almost all of them received a masters degree in computer science as well as the Ph.D. in mathematics. Several are still working towards their degrees but others have gone on to postdoctoral or tenure track positions at first rate universities (in mathematics and other disciplines) while some are working in industry. This has been true for former students and we expect that the ones still working on their degrees will follow paths into both academia and industry. This makes a substantial contribution to human resources in both mathematics and computer science.


    Many papers supported by this grant have been posted on the web and published in, or submitted yo, a range of journals. Both the principal investigators and students have spoken and a wide range of regional, national and international conferences to disseminate the results as well.
